channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bridge Was Their Passion. Then People Started to Die.
item.description: A bridge club was a social draw for scores of older Coloradans. Now, with four members dead from the virus, its future is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

item.title: ‘Will You Help Save My Brother?’: The Scramble to Find Covid-19 Plasma Donors
item.description: A doctor stricken with Covid-19 was running out of options. His family mounted a search for a donor whose plasma might help.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basil Binns II, who had recovered from the coronavirus, was asked to donate plasma to help a stranger battling the infection.

item.title: Married to an Undocumented Immigrant? You May Not Get a Stimulus Check.
item.description: Undocumented immigrants are ineligible for federal payments to help families during the coronavirus pandemic. So are their spouses, even if they are U.S. citizens.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Jonny Arenas, 41, holds hands with his husband in Seattle. Mr. Arenas immigrated from Mexico and his husband is an American citizen.

item.title: Coronavirus Closed Campuses, So College Tours Moved Online
item.description: Colleges are ghost towns, but officials are trying to reach prospective students with virtual visits and Zoom meetings. Can they replicate that face-to-face feeling?
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: When the Yale University campus closed in March, the admissions team moved quickly to shift its programming online.

item.title: Terry Lenzner, Sleuth With a Wide-Ranging Career, Dies at 80
item.description: He prosecuted civil rights violators, investigated the Nixon administration during the Watergate scandal and worked for Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: Terry F. Lenzner, right, with President Richard M. Nixon when Mr. Lenzner headed the administration’s Legal Services Program. Between them was Donald H. Rumsfeld, Mr. Lenzner’s boss at the Office of Economic Opportunity. At right was Dick Cheney, a member of Mr. Rumsfeld's staff at the time.

item.title: Video Shows California Boy, 14, Being Punched by Police Officer
item.description: The police in Rancho Cordova, Calif., and the Sacramento County Sheriff’s Department are investigating the incident, which was captured in a video that was widely shared on social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Sacramento County Sheriff's Department, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A video of the incident made the rounds on social media in posts that accused the officer, who is white, of using excessive force on a youth of color who was carrying a cigar.

item.title: Boeing, Expecting a Long Slump, Will Cut 16,000 Jobs
item.description: The company, which saw sales plunge in the first quarter, said air travel might not recover for years.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: Boeing employees during a shift change at the plant in Renton, Wash., on Tuesday.

item.title: Energy Use in the Coronavirus Era: N.Y.C. Is Waking Up Later
item.description: Some 400 special electric meters in New York apartments provide a shifting view of power use while people are stuck inside.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Overall consumption of electricity is down since the pandemic hit, but energy use in Manhattan apartments has gone up.

item.title: Gilead Claims ‘Positive Data’ to Come From N.I.H. Trial of Remdesivir
item.description: Neither the company nor the institutes discussed the data. Another study reported the drug offered no benefit to severely ill patients.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The antiviral drug remdesivir, developed to fight Ebola, is being evaluated as a treatment for Covid-19.

item.title: What Are California's Stages to Reopen? Newsom Breaks it Down.
item.description: Wednesday: A look at the four phases state leaders laid out to lift stay-at-home orders. Also: Getting creative for gatherings.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A public art installation was aimed at turning boarded-up shopfronts into works of art in Los Angeles. The initiative was started by the street artist Jeremy Novy and Art Share L.A.

item.title: Online Auction to Aid Comic-Book Shops Raises Over $430,000
item.description: Comic-book creators contributed their work, and buyers made their bids on Twitter, to help employees and businesses upended by the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:description: This watercolor, a tribute to people working at the forefront of the pandemic, by the artist David Mack, sold at auction for $2,200.

item.title: On Politics: Another Split-Screen Endorsement
item.description: An ex-nominee backs a presumptive one, and a third-party bid looms: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, Justin Amash, Irrfan Khan: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Live Updates: F.D.A. Plans to Announce Emergency Use of Coronavirus Drug
item.description: The U.S. economy shrank at a 4.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter. Officially, more than 53,000 have died, according to The Times’s count, but death rates suggest the true toll is far greater.

item.title: A Scramble for Virus Apps That Do No Harm
item.description: Dozens of tracking apps for smartphones are being used or developed to help contain the coronavirus pandemic. But there are worries about privacy and hastily written software.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries, Natasha Singer and Aaron Krolik
item.media:description: Singapore’s app uses Bluetooth to identify nearby phones, and the information is stored on the phones unless a person tests positive for the virus and agrees to share the data with contact tracers.

item.title: Stock Market Live Updates and Tracker
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus World News: Live Updates
item.description: Fighting fears and travel bans, countries and businesses are trying to rescue summer vacation. In Bangkok, a high-end restaurant has transformed into an aid operation.
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bakery in Sceaux, France, last week. Locals were confused when the commune’s mayor mandated that people wear masks in public, only for the policy to be overturned two days later by the central government.

item.title: Peace Corps Volunteers Can Get Unemployment Benefits, Officials Say
item.description: In previous years, returned volunteers were not eligible for unemployment benefits, but they will now be covered by the coronavirus relief plan.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: A mother welcoming her daughter home after she served one year with the Peace Corps and finished a two-week quarantine.

item.title: Pug in North Carolina Tests Positive for the Coronavirus, Researchers Say
item.description: A team at Duke University detected the virus in the dog this month.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Jenny Gross
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Winston, a pug who has preliminarily tested positive for the coronavirus, getting swabbed while Sydney McLean, right, holds him.

item.title: Justin Amash Moves Toward a Third-Party Bid for President
item.description: Mr. Amash, an independent congressman from Michigan who left the Republican Party last year, said he was exploring running as a Libertarian, adding new volatility to the race.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan during a town hall event in Grand Rapids, Mich., in May 2019.

item.title: Mfume to Return to Congress, Succeeding Elijah Cummings
item.description: He first held the seat from 1987 to 1996 until he left to serve as president of the N.A.A.C.P. and was replaced by Mr. Cummings, who died in October.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Kweisi Mfume, center, with his wife, Tiffany, left, in Baltimore in February, after winning the Democratic nomination for the congressional seat to represent Baltimore.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Whenever schools finally reopen in the United States, the classroom could be a very different place.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons
item.media:credit: The locations of people who have tested positive in the U.S.

item.title: Trump Administration’s Message on Reopening Continues to Be Contradictory
item.description: The president said the coronavirus wouldn’t come back while Dr. Anthony Fauci said it would be “a bad fall” and the attorney general threatened to sue states for enforcing restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump hosted Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Tuesday to talk about reopening the state.

item.title: Pence Tours Mayo Clinic and Flouts Its Rule That All Visitors Wear a Mask
item.description: The vice president, who leads the White House’s coronavirus task force, said that masks were meant to prevent the spread of the virus and that he was tested regularly and does not have it.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence visited Dennis Nelson, a recovered Covid-19 patient who is now donating his blood for research, during a tour of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., on Tuesday.

item.title: James Beggs, 94, Is Dead; NASA Chief Championed Space Shuttle
item.description: He was on leave during the Challenger disaster in 1986 and resigned shortly after what critics called a leadership vacuum.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Digital Ad Strategy Shows Impact on Voters’ Views of Trump
item.description: Here’s a deeper look at how the Barometer team at Acronym is testing the impact of its Facebook ads.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Treasury Vows to Recoup Virus Relief Aid Claimed by Big Companies
item.description: The Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, said the administration would audit any company that received more than $2 million.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: President Trump and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin during a signing ceremony last week in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington.

item.title: Senate Republicans to Push Ahead on Judges Over Democratic Objections
item.description: The Judiciary Committee is poised to consider the nomination of a McConnell protégé to an influential appeals court, while Democrats say the focus should be on the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: “As soon as we get back in session, we’ll start confirming judges again,” Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said last week.

item.title: Biggest Mall Operator in U.S. Plans to Reopen 49 of Them
item.description: In a memo, Simon Property Group laid out how it planned to open the properties in 10 states between Friday and Monday.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
item.media:description: A closed mall owned by Simon Property Group in Schaumburg, Ill., outside Chicago.

item.title: What We Know About the Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery
item.description: Mr. Arbery, a 25-year-old black man, was chased by armed white residents of a South Georgia neighborhood. He was shot dead during a confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Homes in Glynn County, Ga., where Ahmaud Arbery lived and was killed.

item.title: May Congress Sue the Executive Branch? Court Hears Cases on Subpoena and Border Wall
item.description: A federal appeals court took up two cases testing whether the House can challenge a president in court.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: An appeals court in Washington heard two cases involving disputes between the House and President Trump.

item.title: N.Y. Building Sites Reopen, Carefully, in Sign of Life Gearing Back Up
item.description: More than 5,200 construction projects have reopened in New York City, offering a glimpse of new routines in postpandemic workplaces.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.category: Building and Construction Trade Council of Greater New York
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: At construction sites that are open, workers are getting their temperature taken before their shift begins.
